etymologies: late 18th century; earliest use found in Thomas Pennant (1726–1798), naturalist, traveller, and writer. From post-classical Latin turdinus of or relating to thrushes from classical Latin turdus thrush, also in scientific Latin as Turdus, genus name + -īnus

definitions: Originally: having the form or appearance of a thrush. In later use: belonging to the family Turdidae or subfamily Turdinae, comprising the typical thrushes.
